title: AI Development Foundations
description: Test your understanding of MCP, context management, IDE selection, and security fundamentals.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Model Context Protocol (MCP)?

options.text: To standardize how AI models connect to external tools and data

questions.explanation: MCP acts as a 'USB-C for AI applications' - it standardizes how LLMs connect to databases, APIs, and other tools. This eliminates the need for custom integrations for every tool-model combination.

questions.question: In MCP architecture, what are the three main components?
questions.explanation: MCP uses a three-part architecture: Client (the host application like Claude Desktop), Server (exposes tools and resources), and Model (the LLM that uses the tools).

questions.question: Which AI IDE is best suited for 'deep surgery' across multiple interconnected modules?
questions.explanation: Windsurf (by Codeium) excels at understanding variable flow across your application. Its 'Cascade' flow allows it to plan and execute multi-step changes across frontend, backend, and database more effectively.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the .cursorrules or .windsurfrules file?

options.text: To define project-specific coding standards and context for the AI
To set up version control rules

questions.explanation: These files act as a system prompt injected into every chat session. They define your stack, coding standards, testing requirements, and what the AI should avoid. Without them, the AI might suggest patterns inconsistent with your project.

questions.question: Which security principle should you apply when connecting MCP servers to external services?

options.text: Grant full read/write access for convenience
Principle of least privilege - only grant necessary permissions
Disable all security features for faster performance
Share credentials across all MCP servers

questions.explanation: Always use the principle of least privilege. For example, if you only need to read GitHub issues, use scope 'read:issue' instead of 'repo' which grants full repository control.

questions.question: What is the recommended way to run untrusted MCP servers?

options.text: Directly on the host machine for best performance
Inside a Docker container for isolation

questions.explanation: Container sandboxing isolates untrusted code from your host system. A malicious MCP server running in Docker cannot easily access your credentials, sensitive files, or execute arbitrary code on your machine.

questions.question: What library makes building MCP servers trivial in Python?
questions.explanation: FastMCP is a high-level library that simplifies MCP server development. You can expose tools using simple decorators like @mcp.tool(), making it easy to add custom functionality to AI assistants.

questions.question: Which critical operations should always require explicit user confirmation in MCP servers?
questions.explanation: High-risk, potentially destructive operations like DELETE, DROP TABLE, and force push should require Human-in-the-Loop (HITL) confirmation. Configure your MCP servers to flag these tools as 'requires_approval'.

questions.question: What are the three layers of context in AI development, from most permanent to most ephemeral?

options.text: Project Constitution → Task Context → Dynamic Context
Global Settings → Local Settings → Runtime Config

questions.explanation: The three layers are: 1) Project Constitution (CLAUDE.md, .cursorrules) - permanent project rules, 2) Task Context - session-specific descriptions and comments, 3) Dynamic Context - real-time MCP resources and file reads that change during execution.

questions.question: According to the IDE Selection Framework, which tool is recommended for validating a new idea before investing significant development time?

options.text: Cursor - for its speed and familiar IDE experience
Claude Code - for its superior reasoning capabilities
Antigravity - for the fastest path from idea to deployed prototype
Windsurf - for its deep context understanding

questions.explanation: The multi-tool workflow recommends: Validate quickly in Antigravity (1 hour) → Develop properly in Cursor (1-2 days) → Refactor in Windsurf → Architect in Claude Code. This lets you fail fast on bad ideas while investing properly in good ones.
